context:

Its looks like we are going full Star Wars.  I hate to think what is going on in space right now.

replies.context: You'd be surprised what DARPA is up to. Remember the vaunted night vision improvements in Desert Storm? We (TCATA) were working on them at Ft Hod in the night vision labs in the 1970s. What you see the military using now is at least 20 years behind what is being developed. Probably 30 years behind now, with computer power increasing. We did all the work on the night vision with IBM computers that held (GASP!) 260 GB of data, were 20 feet long, 6 feet tall and used the same amount of power as the average household. Imagine what they can do with the available computing power and AI capabilities of 2019? My laptop now has 4 times the amount of storage as the old IBMs.

context: So pull the troops out of the middle east then. Let the drones take care of ISIS and the rest.

replies.context: a faraday cage will provide no protection for a nuclear power plant.

replies.context: The V-1 "buzz bomb" was an example that drones work.  They are just getting cheaper and more prolific now that you can purchase them commercially.

context: drone use against high value fixed targets such as oil refineries is completely different from their use in a battle field environment.  defense against fixed target attacks is a problem increase of orders of magnitude.  good luck saudi arabia.
there is NO defense.  you can run, but you can't hide.

I am fro Israel. This is exactly like the Israeli drone. The whole idea of a massive drone attack confusing enemy’s radars and jamming their electronics goes back to the 80s when israel neutralized the Russian/Syrian radars in Lebanon and then shot down some 80 Syrian jets in that day.
